content.headline: SurveillanceU
content.subheadline: Has Virtual Proctoring Gone Too far?
content.author: YR Staff
content.seo_description: SurveillanceU: Has Virtual Proctoring Gone Too far?

intro.text:
Sergine Beaubrun never thought she would have to grab her laptop and stand on her church‚Äôs boardroom table, putting her face right next to the ceiling light, just to take her mock bar exam. She says that ExamSoft, which is often used to remotely proctor the single most important test a law student will take, had difficulty registering--or even detecting--Beaubrun‚Äôs face.

<>

On the day of her actual bar exam, Beaubrun sought help from an attorney she found on Twitter, who suggested that Beaubrun avoid backlighting in order to increase the contrast between her and her background, so that Examsoft would register her face. The tip worked.

But her technical difficulties left Beaubrun bewildered. If these were the hurdles she had to jump through just to take her bar exam, what would it be like once she started her career? ‚ÄúIt's just like, was this profession really meant for me? The software isn't. It shouldn't have taken me jumping on a table and going this close to light, just so you guys could recognize me,‚Äù Beaubrun said, ‚ÄúI hope that this profession recognizes me as a person when I enter it.‚Äù These kinds of questions are what students are asking when proctoring software fails to recognize them, or interferes with their ability to perform at their best. It‚Äôs that serious. So how did we get here?

intro.title: The Rise of Virtual Proctoring in the Pandemic
intro.text:
Attending virtual classes ‚Äî and taking virtual tests ‚Äî isn‚Äôt ideal for anyone. All through the pandemic, faculty and students alike have struggled to create the genuine connections and rich dialogues that more easily take hold when everyone‚Äôs in a room together. Technical challenges range from random computer glitches to missing out on important bits of the lecture when the WiFi fades. Zoom fatigue spares no one. And of course, with everything on the computer, professors need new tools to make sure their learning environments are fair, which requires an ability to prevent and catch cheating on tests.

Some university administrators believed they‚Äôd found a solution to this last concern by contracting with virtual proctoring companies like, say, Examsoft, which was founded in 1998. Since then, it has proctored 75,000,000 exams, according to the company website.

Examsoft isn‚Äôt the only such product on the market. Another large-scale virtual proctoring service is ProctorU, which reported proctoring over 5,000,000 exams. Jarrod Morgan, CEO of ProctorU, told YR Media: ‚ÄúWe feel very strongly that we should protect the education industry and the integrity of exams.‚Äù

When the pandemic hit and campuses closed, universities needed to move fast to accommodate their new reality. Before 2020, students would take tests in the same room, and the professor, a teaching assistant, or some other in-person human proctor could be there to collect exams and check in if necessary. Remote learning left universities that normally operated on campus with fewer options. ‚ÄúThe pandemic put everyone in a situation where they had to use this,‚Äù Jarrod Morgan said of virtual proctoring. ‚ÄúNothing really changed about our service, but the fact that we were not really an option in 2020: we were a requirement to continue to work.‚Äù

I‚Äôm a freshman virtually attending classes at University of California at Santa Cruz, and I‚Äôve heard lots of stories from students using proctoring software for tests. By and large, the chatter among my friends has not been good.

Conversations like these about the sheer invasiveness of the software inspired me to spearhead this investigation. I spent several months looking into the rise of various virtual proctoring companies, the effects they‚Äôre having on students, and whether the benefits outweigh the costs.

Students I spoke with reported that using proctoring software added significant anxiety to the already-stressful situation of taking a high-stakes test, and that the anxiety could affect their performance. Many also expressed concern that these companies violated their rights in one way or another. Some raised issues related to digital privacy, others about racial and other forms of bias within the technology. Our data analysis of over 80 Change.org petitions against virtual proctoring software in the United States revealed these same themes.

intro.title: How Virtual Proctoring Works
intro.text: The variety of online proctoring services on the market today is vast. For the sake of this investigation, we focused on three types: 1) automated tools using artificial intelligence (AI) in place of live proctors, 2) those involving live proctors, and 3) lockdown browsers that prevent students from switching tabs, without a proctor involved.

intro.title: Examsoft
intro.text: Examsoft technology goes back to the days of floppy disks; in 1999, the company filed a patent that outlined plans to develop technology that secures exams in computer environments. Today, the company offers two features that use facial recognition and AI for automated proctoring: When students sit down to take a test, ExamID uses facial recognition technology, or ‚Äúfacematching analysis,‚Äù to verify that they are who they claim to be. ExamMonitor, a second product, records video and audio of students all through the test-taking experience before uploading the footage to a third-party proctoring service that uses automated intelligence to monitor data including gaze, eye movements and sound. A (human) professional from Examsoft can then sift through behaviors, flag any unusual behavior and decide if they are punishable, ‚Äúgiving the institution the final review,‚Äù according to the ExamSoft website. Third parties that ExamSoft works with also ‚Äúuse the exam videos to refine their artificial intelligence to improve the accuracy of their virtual proctoring software,‚Äù according to a letter from ExamSoft that addresses concerns with the software. ExamSoft says, after one year, they ‚Äúautomatically delete an exam-taker‚Äôs video.‚Äù

intro.title: ProctorU
intro.text: ProctorU combines automated and live proctoring. The company collects biometric data and then outsources analysis to third-party partners to verify student identities and track keystrokes and other data points during test-taking, according to ProctorU's 2019 Technical Security Overview. But that‚Äôs just the automated aspect of its service. With ProctorU, real, actual people sit down with you (well, via your screen, not in the room) and watch you take your test. While the proctors monitor students through their webcams, the students YR Media interviewed said that they couldn‚Äôt see the proctors at all, and could only talk to a disembodied voice. ProctorU CEO Morgan said live proctors can make active interventions. For example, if a test-taker is ‚Äúconstantly looking out the window,‚Äù Morgan said, the proctor can remind the student: ‚Äú‚ÄôHey, I need you to keep your focus here.‚Äô It could be [the student] picking up their cell phone or could be something as flagrant as picking up an answer key.‚Äù

intro.title: Respondus
intro.text: Finally, Respondus, while not involving any proctors, purports to preserve academic integrity by shutting down a student‚Äôs ability to switch tabs, ostensibly preventing them from looking up answers online. According to the company‚Äôs website, 100,000,000 exams are proctored through their service each year, and they also report that third-party services use Respondus in their assessment programs. It‚Äôs the least complicated out of the three. However, students still report problems with it.

stories.title: When Software Can‚Äôt See You
stories.text:
Racial bias in AI is nothing new, and in fact, we here at YR have covered this multiple times in stories like ‚ÄúIn the Black Mirror,‚Äù ‚ÄúErase Your Face,‚Äù ‚ÄúJay-Z Beefs with AI,‚Äù Fake ISH‚Äù and ‚ÄúHidden No More.‚Äù Neither are stories like Sergine Beaubrun‚Äôs unique. Areeb Been Khan, another student attempting to take his bar exam, told YR Media that it took five business days before Examsoft recognized his face at all. ‚ÄúThat was anxiety inducing and it made it difficult to study information that was going to impact my livelihood,‚Äù Been Khan said. ExamSoft issued an email to Been Khan: if he failed to get the software to detect his face by the deadline, that could affect his registration status to sit for the exam.

Been Khan said he emailed Examsoft on a Monday, got a written response on a Wednesday, and when that wasn‚Äôt sufficient, he called customer support Friday morning but couldn‚Äôt get through because of a long wait. After selecting the option of an automated call back, he finally received help Friday evening.

Been Khan said that when customer service called him back, an associate made changes that eventually permitted him to take the test. ‚ÄúHe said straight up ‚Ä¶ ‚Äòsometimes our program just needs like an updated data set ‚Ä¶ like a baseline for your face,‚Äô which proves to me that they didn‚Äôt have a baseline for my face,‚Äù Been Khan said. ‚ÄúThere's racism in technology, and that's kind of just what it comes down to, at least for me.‚Äù

Big tech giants like IBM, Microsoft, and Amazon, all have a track record for creating Artificial Intelligence that carries a gender and racial bias, according to Joy Buolamwini, an AI researcher working at MIT who has studied this phenomenon extensively. Buolamwini says that because faces used to test the software are of white men, leaving out women and people of color, the software is only ‚Äúoptimized for a small portion of the world.‚Äù

As these issues became more prevalent during the pandemic, and more allegations similar to Been Khan‚Äôs and Beaubrun‚Äôs came to light, the U.S. government began to take notice. Six U.S. Senators wrote a letter to Sebastian Vos, the Chief Executive Officer of ExamSoft, in December 2020. The lawmakers asked ExamSoft to outline plans that ensure the civil rights of students of color and students with disabilities. The letter cites numerous media reports of ExamSoft falsely flagging these students for cheating.

ExamSoft responded to the senators‚Äô letter more or less by saying: that facial recognition technology that we use... it isn‚Äôt ours. They deny that there is any implicit bias in their products and say that the more common difficulties for exam-takers are internet connectivity, poor picture quality, and lighting issues. Responding to concerns about how the software could unfairly flags students with disabilities, ExamSoft says they are not involved with granting accommodations and that it‚Äôs up to institutions to make those accommodations when using the software.

The ExamSoft letter signed by Vos said, ‚ÄúWe have investigated whether there have been any systemic issues with ExamID due to individual exam-takers‚Äô race or gender indentification. It would be a key priority to resolve any susch issues, but we found none.‚Äù

stories.title: The Cost of Virtual Proctoring
stories.text:
<>

Andrea Kohlenberg feels ProctorU violated her rights ‚Äî and she‚Äôs taking the company to court.

Before she took her LSAT ‚Äî the required test for admission to law school ‚Äî Kohlenberg said she was totally fine with the idea of being proctored. ‚ÄúIt makes sense in theory,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThese are major exams. Cheating would be really bad academically.‚Äù But as Kohlenberg learned some of the things ProctorU would require from her, she got increasingly worried.

<>‚ÄúMy initial concern was security on my laptop. If they can take control on my computer, I have sensitive data on my computer. That would be serious if someone else got that. I have medical information and documents. I didn‚Äôt know if those would be safe.‚Äù said Kohlenberg. <>

Kohlenberg lives in Illinois, where the Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) was designed to regulate the storage and purchase of data.

According to BIPA, any company that collects any biometric information must do three things: protect that data using a ‚Äúreasonable standard of care within the private entity‚Äôs industry‚Äù while they still need it, destroy any biometric data once it‚Äôs no longer useful to the company, and provide a timetable to the public for when the data will be destroyed.

Kohlenberg and two other students filed a civil suit, alleging that the company failed to do all three of those things.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one thing if you get your SSN stolen, you can get your social number changed. But if someone steals your biometrics, those are things you can‚Äôt change about yourself,‚Äù Kohlenberg said.

stories.title: College Governments Take On The Fight
stories.text:
<>

Kohlenberg‚Äôs story is echoed by two other students we talked to. Talha Sarfraz Ahmad and Mohamed Amine Bouftas are trying to bring about change at Purdue University by using the power of student government to push back against virtual proctoring services.

Ahmad was spurred to action by an experience he had with Respondus. He said that when he first tried to use it, Respondus locked him out of his iPad for eight hours. To make matters worse, because all of his notes were on that iPad, Ahmad had to rush to the student library to print out his notes. YR found that out of 80 petitions on Change.org, 33 petitions made complaints against Respondus.

Ahmad was infuriated. With Bouftas‚Äô help, they drafted a resolution against virtual proctoring services at Purdue.

<>Ahmad said, ‚ÄúI would argue that using these ... built a lot of suspicion between professors and students. And when so many people fall into problems like being falsely flagged for cheating or things like that, it makes me wonder, like, is this really achieving the objective of education?‚Äù<>

Apart from his personal frustrations with Respondus, Ahmad has broader concerns about virtual proctoring. For example, he brought up concerns that virtual proctoring companies are outsourcing cheap labor abroad. YR was able to confirm this phenomenon through LinkedIn searches that turned up proctors in countries such as the Philippines and Mexico.

<>

Students aren‚Äôt the only ones taking a stand against virtual proctoring services. Some colleges discourage it. The Academic Senate at San Francisco State University (SFSU) passed a resolution that makes a case to restrict or ban the use of third-party proctoring. ‚ÄúThird-party remote proctoring is expressly designed to minimize cheating and rarely provides any student support,‚Äù the resolution states. ‚ÄúThis casts faculty in the role of police catching cheaters, rather faculty acting as mentors to facilitate student success.‚Äù

SFSU Professor Dr. Jackson Wilson, the vice chair of the academic senate at SFSU, helped author the SFSU resolution after hearing multiple concerns from students and faculty. He described virtual proctoring software as ‚Äúa troublesome service ‚Ä¶ that we should be highly suspicious of.‚Äù

However, Andrew Roderick, assistant vice president of academic technology at SFSU, said the resolution is non-binding and is not policy. He knows of one program that uses proctoring software on its culminating exam required for graduation.

Roderick said in an email, ‚ÄúBased on their experience using remote proctoring software, they are unlikely to use it in the future as it presented a number of logistical and technical challenges to the group of students participating in the exam.‚Äù

The resolutions passed by student governments and faculty are usually not obligatory, and universities make exceptions to use virtual third-party proctoring for certain programs. CSU Office of the Chancellor wrote a memorandum asking campus leaders to address concerns with virtual proctoring but stopped short of banning the software. UCSB Faculty Association made a similar gesture by writing a letter asking the university to curb the use of ProctorU (which the university appears to have ignored).

<>

Filing a petition online is another popular tactic for making a statement against virtual proctoring software, and sometimes it works. The City University of New York‚Äôs petition, ‚ÄúDo Not Let CUNY Violate Student Privacy,‚Äù gained more than 28,000 signatures. In an update to the petition on Change.org, Aharon Grama, the chief of staff of CUNY‚Äôs undergraduate government, wrote that he is fairly certain that the university discontinued the use of virtual proctoring software after experiencing difficulties with ProctorTrack.

stories.title: A Pandemic Trend That Bends
stories.text:
We‚Äôve seen the impacts these virtual proctoring services are having on students now, during the pandemic. But as the vaccine rollout continues and the country starts to reopen, what can we expect from ProctorU, Respondus, and Examsoft in the future?

UCSC‚Äôs Vice Provost Herbie Lee said his institution can roll money left over for ProctorU on its $200,000 purchase order into the 2021-22 academic year, authorizing continuous funding for the software.

YR uncovered new patents for other virtual proctoring services, including one pending patent that works by positioning a camera directly behind students, watching over them as they take an exam. Another pending patent filed in June 2020 outlined plans for headgear that looks like Google Glass that students would wear so the device could monitor them during a test.

<>

ProctorU CEO Jarrod Morgan said at the end of the day, it's up to schools to decide whether they want to discipline students when irregularities are flagged. ProctorU just provides the proctors and the recordings.

So what are some of the alternatives out there? What are students asking for?

Bouftas, who helped Ahmad draft a resolution against virtual proctoring at Purdue, suggested just using Zoom. ‚ÄúAll they do is record your webcam and your screen, and they have access to audio. Zoom is a lot less invasive than Examity or ProctorIO,‚Äù Bouftas said. ‚ÄúAnother thing we tried to address is modifying the way assessments are given, so that cheating is harder to do.‚Äù

Mohamad Bouftas and Talha Ahmad continue to discuss the bill they passed with Purdue‚Äôs senate, sparking campuswide awareness of proctoring services and the impact they can have on students. Sergine Beaubrun completed the bar exam and is now working towards becoming a criminal lawyer and prosecutor focused on fighting injustice. Meanwhile, Andrea Kohlenberg remains a class action plaintiff and representative for others suing ProctorU over their experience with the LSAT.

‚ÄúWe're all in this together,‚Äù Beaubrun said. ‚ÄúLet's fight for a better system.‚Äù

chat.text: It‚Äôs been a year since our schools across the country started shutting down. Today, millions of us are still not back in classrooms, or in hybrid school. Which means many of us are still learning virtually. What does that look like? Here‚Äôs what the stats show: We‚Äôre stressed. We‚Äôre anxious. We‚Äôre having trouble sleeping. We‚Äôre unmotivated.
As students and teachers, we‚Äôre reflecting how the last year in virtual learning has been and how we feel about going back to school.
